chapter.summary: Covers the management of a suspected stye in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a suspected stye in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a person presents with a suspected stye:

  • Arrange emergency hospital admission if there are signs of significant periorbital or orbital cellulitis. See the CKS topics on Cellulitis - acute and Sepsis for more information.
  • Arrange an urgent referral to an ophthalmologist (to be seen within two weeks) if a malignant eyelid tumour is suspected. See the CKS topic on Skin cancers - recognition and referral for more information.
  • If there are typical clinical features of a stye, offer reassurance and self-care advice:
    • Advise that a stye is usually self-limiting and rarely causes serious complications.
    • Apply a warm compress (for example, using a clean flannel that has been rinsed with hot water) to the closed eyelid of the affected eye for 5–10 minutes 2–4 times daily until the stye drains or resolves.
    • Advise the person not to attempt to puncture the stye.
    • Advise to avoid using eye makeup or contact lenses until the area has healed.
    • The NHS information leaflet Stye and the patient information leaflet Stye available on the www.patient.info website may be helpful.
  • For a painful external stye, consider treatment in primary care for symptom relief:
    • Plucking the eyelash from the infected follicle, to facilitate drainage.
    • Incision and drainage of the stye using a fine sterile needle, if appropriate, performed by a healthcare professional with suitable experience and expertise.
  • Do not routinely prescribe a topical antibiotic.
    • Consider prescribing a topical antibiotic only if there are clinical features of spreading infection causing conjunctivitis, such as copious muco-purulent discharge. See the CKS topic on Conjunctivitis - infective for more information on diagnosis and management.
  • Manage any co-existing conditions such as blepharitis or acne rosacea, to reduce the risk of recurrence. See the CKS topics on Blepharitis and Rosacea - acne for more information.
  • Refer the person to an ophthalmologist for possible specialist incision and drainage if:
    • The stye does not improve or resolve with management in primary care.
    • An internal stye is particularly large and painful.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of a stye in primary care are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2017], the College of Optometrists clinical management guideline Hordeolum [College of Optometrists, 2018], the Cochrane systematic review Non‐surgical interventions for acute internal hordeolum [Lindsley, 2017], and expert opinion in review articles on styes and chalazions [Skorin, 2002], on eyelid conditions [Peralejo et al, 2008; Gupta et al, 2014; Carlisle, 2015; Sun, 2019], and on other eye conditions [Mueller and McStay, 2008; Sethuraman and Kamat, 2009].

Arranging emergency hospital admission for suspected periorbital or orbital cellulitis
  • The recommendation to arrange emergency admission for a person with suspected periorbital or orbital cellulitis is based on expert opinion in review articles [Mueller and McStay, 2008; Sun, 2019].
    • Orbital cellulitis is a medical emergency which can progress rapidly and lead to loss of vision and cerebral complications (such as meningitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis, and cerebral abscess) [Mueller and McStay, 2008].
    • Orbital cellulitis is a rare but potentially sight-threatening and life-threatening complication which needs specialist imaging and antibiotic treatment if suspected [Sun, 2019].
Arranging urgent referral for suspected cancer
  • The recommendation to arrange an urgent referral if a person has a suspected eyelid tumour is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2017] and expert opinion in review articles [Mueller and McStay, 2008; Gupta et al, 2014; Sun, 2019].
    • Expert opinion in a review article notes that a biopsy may be needed if there is a recurrent lesion in the same location, to exclude malignancy [Mueller and McStay, 2008].
    • This approach is supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
Offering self-management advice
  • The recommendation to apply a warm compress is based on the College of Optometrists clinical management guideline [College of Optometrists, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Skorin, 2002; Peralejo et al, 2008; Sethuraman and Kamat, 2009; Gupta et al, 2014; Carlisle, 2015; Sun, 2019].
    • Regular application of a warm compress accelerates pointing of the lesion and its spontaneous drainage [Skorin, 2002]. 
    • CKS notes that a Cochrane systematic review did not find any evidence for or against the effectiveness of non‐surgical interventions for the treatment of an internal hordeolum [Lindsley, 2017].
  • The recommendation to avoid puncture of a stye by the person themselves is based on two UK case reports, which highlighted potential serious complications such as periorbital cellulitis [Benton and Karkanevatos, 2007] and periorbital necrotizing fasciitis [Raja et al, 2008].
  • The recommendation to avoid eye makeup or contact lens use is pragmatic based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Offering management for a painful external stye
  • The recommendations to consider plucking the eyelash from the affected hair follicle or to perform incision and drainage in primary care are extrapolated from the College of Optometrists clinical management guideline [College of Optometrists, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Skorin, 2002; Mueller and McStay, 2008; Peralejo et al, 2008; Sethuraman and Kamat, 2009].
    • Plucking the eyelash may promote healing as infection often centers on the base of the eyelash follicle [Sethuraman and Kamat, 2009; College of Optometrists, 2018].
    • If an eyelash is seen to extend from the involved stye, removal of the eyelash can initiate healing of the lesion by creating an effective drainage channel [Skorin, 2002; Peralejo et al, 2008].
    • Incision and drainage using a sterile needle or blade is a possible treatment option [Skorin, 2002; Mueller and McStay, 2008; Peralejo et al, 2008]. This approach is supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
Use of topical antibiotic treatment
  • The recommendations on the indication for topical antibiotic treatment is based on the College of Optometrists clinical management guideline [College of Optometrists, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Skorin, 2002; Sethuraman and Kamat, 2009].
    • A review article notes that regarding internal styes, because the infection is deep within the lid tissue, the topical application of antibiotics is usually ineffective [Skorin, 2002].
    • An additional review article notes that topical antibiotics do not affect the course of a stye [Sethuraman and Kamat, 2009].
    • The College of Optometrists clinical management guideline recommends topical antibiotics if there is copious muco-purulent discharge [College of Optometrists, 2018].
    • CKS notes that a Cochrane systematic review did not find any evidence for or against the effectiveness of non‐surgical interventions for the treatment of an internal hordeolum [Lindsley, 2017].
    • This approach is supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
Management of co-existing conditions
  • The recommendation to manage co-existing blepharitis to reduce the risk of recurrence is based on the College of Optometrists clinical management guideline [College of Optometrists, 2018], and is also pragmatic based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Arranging referral to an ophthalmologist
  • The recommendation to consider referral to an ophthalmologist for severe and non-resolving cases to consider surgical drainage is based on the College of Optometrists clinical management guideline [College of Optometrists, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Sethuraman and Kamat, 2009; Gupta et al, 2014].
